title: 106_hr2651
content: The Act may be cited as the "Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999" and includes a table of contents. The "Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999" includes provisions such as eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements, exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions, changing the definition of group practice, delaying implementation of 1993 ownership referral changes, excluding certain medical devices from regulations, permitting supervision of clinical laboratory services by independent contractor pathologists, and specifying the effective date of the amendments. Eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. The text chunk amends the Social Security Act to clarify ownership or investment interests in entities through equity. It also includes conforming amendments to subsections (b) and (c) of the Act. The text chunk makes conforming amendments to subsections (b) and (c) of the Social Security Act regarding ownership or investment interests in publicly traded securities and mutual funds. The text chunk includes amendments to subsection (c) of the Social Security Act, specifically regarding ownership or investment interests in publicly traded securities and mutual funds. Amendments to subsection (c) of the Social Security Act involve changes such as redesignating paragraphs, striking subsections, and modifying ownership and investment interests. Amendments to subsection (c) of the Social Security Act include transferring paragraphs, striking subsections, and modifying ownership and investment interests. Amendments to subsection (c) of the Social Security Act involve changes such as striking certain clauses and paragraphs, and modifying rules for faculty compensation relationships with entities. SEC. 3. EXCEPTIONS TO OWNERSHIP REFERRAL PROHIBITIONS. Revisions to Exception for In-Office Ancillary Services include repealing the site-of-service requirement in Section 1877 of the Social Security Act. This allows services to be personally furnished by the referring physician, a physician in the same group practice, or individuals under their supervision. The new paragraph added to Section 1877 of the Social Security Act defines general supervision as the legal responsibility of a physician or group practice for services performed by individuals under their supervision. The new paragraph clarifies that general supervision involves the legal responsibility of a physician or group practice for services performed by individuals under their supervision. The text chunk clarifies the responsibilities of physicians for ensuring individuals meet licensure requirements, and includes amendments related to group practice ownership. The text chunk clarifies the treatment of physician owners of group practices and includes a conforming amendment related to ancillary services. The text chunk includes a conforming amendment related to ancillary services and clarifies the exception for services furnished in a rural area. SEC. 4. CHANGE IN DEFINITION OF GROUP PRACTICE. Section 1877(h)(4) of the Social Security Act is amended to define a physician as a 'member' of a group if they are an owner or a bona fide employee, or both, of the group. SEC. 5. DELAY IN IMPLEMENTATION OF 1993 OWNERSHIP REFERRAL CHANGES UNTIL FINAL REGULATIONS. The amendments from the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 regarding ownership referral changes will not apply to any referrals made before final regulations are promulgated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 6. EXCLUSION OF INTRAOCULAR LENSES, EYEGLASSES, AND CONTACT LENSES. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to exclude intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. SEC. 7 permits pathologists who are independent contractors to supervise clinical laboratory services. Section 1877(h)(6)(H) of the Social Security Act is amended to exclude intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. Section 1877(b)(2) is amended to allow pathologists who are independent contractors to supervise clinical laboratory services. The amendments made by this Act apply to referrals made on or after the enactment date, regardless of regulations being in place.
